H0.text: To enhance the effectiveness of friction, oil is applied to the moving parts of machines that rub against each other, reducing wear and preventing damage.

H1.text: Oil is applied to moving parts that rub against each other in machines to increase the efficiency of the machine.

H2.text: To provide an additional source of energy is why oil is necessary in machines that are often full of moving parts that rub against each other, where a lubricant such as oil is applied.

H3.text: Oil is necessary to produce more thermal energy on the machine, as machines often have moving parts that rub against each other and oil is applied to them.

A4.text: Lubrication is required for correct operation of mechanical systems such as pistons, pumps, cams, bearings, turbines, gears, roller chains, and cutting tools.

A5.text: Without lubrication, the pressure between the surfaces in proximity would generate enough heat for rapid surface damage which, in a coarsened condition, could literally weld the surfaces together, causing seizure.
